html:
Mumbai: India's equity indices fell over 1% on Monday, mirroring concerns on Wall Street as Chinese company DeepSeek's latest AI model with its thrifty underpinnings threatens to lay waste to the high-spending strategy that's fuelled the surge in Nvidia, Microsoft, Alphabet, Meta and other tech stocks.

Tired of too many ads? Remove Ads

US tech stocks tanked on concerns over DeepSeek's latest R1 release, considered stiff competition for OpenAI's ChatGPT, Google Gemini, Claude and others. According to some reports, DeepSeek has overtaken ChatGPT and others as the top-rated free app on the Apple Store in the US, UK and China.

An earnings slump and uncertainty over US tariffs contributed to the unease in India with Nifty closing below 23,000 for the first time since June 2024 with overseas investors continuing to sell.

Nasdaq Tanks
The NSE Nifty fell 263.05 points, or 1.14%, to close at 22,829.15. The BSE's Sensex declined 824.29 points, or 1.1%, to end at 75,366.17. Both the benchmarks are down about 3.5% in 2025.

Tired of too many ads? Remove Ads

In the US, the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite was down 3.3% at the time of going to press as investors questioned US dominance in developing AI models after DeepSeek was said to have built its platform in China at a much lower cost.

"We have seen broad-based selling in the market because of unexciting earnings across most of the pockets," said Pankaj Pandey, head of retail research at ICICI Securities. "Newfound concerns around China's DeepSeek AI have also impacted US tech-led AI models, which in turn could impact many Indian IT companies which had been investing in and looking to build capacities around these AI, affecting the monetisation and use cases... amid cheaper alternatives."

The NSE IT index plunged 3.4%, while various other sector indices such as media, metals and pharma fell 2-5%. The Nifty Midcap 150 dropped 2.8% and the Nifty Small-cap 250 fell 3.6%. Out of 4,234 shares traded on the BSE, 532 advanced and 3588 declined on Monday.

Elsewhere in Asia, China remained flat, Hong Kong rose 0.66%, South Korea gained 0.85% and Taiwan rose 1%.

The pan-Europe index Stoxx 600 fell 0.07% .

Back in India, foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) net sold shares worth Rs 5,015.46 crore. Domestic institutions were buyers to the tune of Rs 6,642.15 crore. Foreign investors have pulled out Rs 66,265 crore from Indian equities so far this year.

Nifty's India Volatility Index or VIX-commonly known as the fear index of the market-jumped 8.3% to 18.13 levels on Monday.
